Answer: All Fantastic Four movies have scored low on Rotten Tomatoes. For some reason, it’s just hard to make a good Fantastic Four film. Everything has been tried but nothing works. Someone even had the nutty idea to cast a popular African-American actor to play Johnny Storm. That gimmick didn’t work either. But here’s an interesting irony. There is a parody of the Fantastic Four which is a critically acclaimed box office success and audiences love it. It is called The Incredibles. The incredibles is obviously the Fantastic Four but done in such a way that Pixar Animation Studios can’t get sued. ButAll Fantastic Four movies have scored low on Rotten Tomatoes. For some reason, it’s just hard to make a good Fantastic Four film. Everything has been tried but nothing works. Someone even had the nutty idea to cast a popular African-American actor to play Johnny Storm. That gimmick didn’t work either. But here’s an interesting irony. There is a parody of the Fantastic Four which is a critically acclaimed box office success and audiences love it. It is called The Incredibles. The incredibles is obviously the Fantastic Four but done in such a way that Pixar Animation Studios can’t get sued. But any moron knows the Incredibles is really the Fantastic Four.What Marvel Studios should do is analyze and consider what it is that Pixar got right and what it is that previous Fantastic Four movie makers got wrong. What might solve the problem is to make a Fantastic Four script that is very *character* driven instead of action driven or special effects driven. Just screen-write a sensitive story and show all the special effects action at the end of the movie. The strategy was successfully done before with the 2014 film Birdman which went on to win an Oscar for best movie.

Answer: Because Germany is for obvious historical reasons reluctant to become a military force. That is a very simplified view though.During the cold war, Germany had indeed a strong military force. Several thousand tanks, hundreds of aircraft, 500,000 troops. Artillery, submarines…..Then came the end of the cold war and a very costly reunification. Military budgets all over the continent were cut, the existential threat of the Warsaw pact and now Russia was non-existing. The so-called peace dividend was lived to the fullest degree. For 20 years, we have not increased the budget with inflation, cuttinBecause Germany is for obvious historical reasons reluctant to become a military force. That is a very simplified view though.During the cold war, Germany had indeed a strong military force. Several thousand tanks, hundreds of aircraft, 500,000 troops. Artillery, submarines…..Then came the end of the cold war and a very costly reunification. Military budgets all over the continent were cut, the existential threat of the Warsaw pact and now Russia was non-existing. The so-called peace dividend was lived to the fullest degree. For 20 years, we have not increased the budget with inflation, cutting money and troops so that our Bundeswehr is not a fighting force anymore.Now, we have 180,000 troops and 80,000 officials “working” for the Bundeswehr. There is a huge administrative cost to the troops, any new procurements are years delayed and increasingly costly. The Bundeswehr does not attract the much-needed specialists for the service in the armed forces is nothing that is admired in the society of pacifists Germany has become. Whenever a world crisis emerges, the go-to reflex is diplomacy. Now with Syria, politicians mean we should act. They mean a nice convention where everyone talks about their differences.

The biggest limiter of German capability remains a somewhat meagre navy when compared to UK and France. Compare that with their naval expansion in the lead up to both world wars.Like Japan and for many of the same reasons the German military has been built around a defensive role. A resurgent and inTwo failed attempts in the 1st half of the 20th century to build a wider German “empire” that resulted in the death of almost 100 million combatants and civilians.Any sign of Germany building a greater offensive capability would justifiably be viewed with some trepidation by many of its neighbours. The biggest limiter of German capability remains a somewhat meagre navy when compared to UK and France. Compare that with their naval expansion in the lead up to both world wars.Like Japan and for many of the same reasons the German military has been built around a defensive role. This seldom ended up well for Europe, or for Germany for that matter.Following WW2, Germany was rebuilt with their military very much as a minor issue and for a defensive role. I think that they were not allowed to have a military force until the mid 1950’s. (Might be wrong anI am assuming that you mean in the here and now.The simple reason is that Germany choses it to be so.Obviously Germany is known and respected for being a technologicvally advanced state but this doesn’t automatically equate to having a strong military.In the past Grmany and/or the Germanic states had a powerful military. This seldom ended up well for Europe, or for Germany for that matter.Following WW2, Germany was rebuilt with their military very much as a minor issue and for a defensive role. I think that they were not allowed to have a military force until the mid 1950’s. (Might be wrong and I can’t be bothered to check).Obviously, in light of the past, German military spending has been tilted towards defence. No doubt, if Germany were to do more when it comes to NATO involvement outside of Europe, there would be comments about “The Condor legion “ on the rise again. (I sometimes get the feeling that Germany cannot win).When it comes to the present German government spending I understand that the German military is way down on the list behind social and green matters.However this is currently at 1.36% of GDP which doesn’t mark it out so differently from many in Europe and actually puts it ahead of Spain by quite a distance. France spends 1.78% and Britain 2% the USA spends approximately 3.2%.

Answer: I wouldn’t use the term “weaker” here. The Bundeswehr since the 1950s has been focussed on defence - initially against a Soviet invasion. These days they view an increasingly-assertive Russia with suspicion. They lack the global reach of powers like Britain and France, which both operate “blue water” navies with expeditionary capabilities.But Germany, France and the UK face similar problems - they have plenty of military hardware, but cannot attract the trained personnel to operate them. People in all three nations, are making far too much money in the civilian workforce; attracting these taleI wouldn’t use the term “weaker” here. The Bundeswehr since the 1950s has been focussed on defence - initially against a Soviet invasion. These days they view an increasingly-assertive Russia with suspicion. They lack the global reach of powers like Britain and France, which both operate “blue water” navies with expeditionary capabilities.But Germany, France and the UK face similar problems - they have plenty of military hardware, but cannot attract the trained personnel to operate them. People in all three nations, are making far too much money in the civilian workforce; attracting these talented people into the armed forces would seriously weaken Germany’s booming economy.The acknowledged excellence of German engineers and manufacturers does not find its way into the military marketplace. At least, not to the same extent as into the lucrative civilian export markets which Germany supplies so readily and efficiently. What a change from 1934, when German industrialists camped outside Hitler’s office door!

Answer: In 2003 I was working for Cisco Systems and at the time we learned that the US Department of Defense had worked with Intel and other chip manufacturers to install in their hardware the ability to remotely disable any device using their technology with a certain radio frequency. Supposedly, this technology was used to help cripple the Iraqi air defense system when the US invaded.This was important to Cisco because we were working in security and cryptography and the NSA was forever trying to get us to corrupt our products so they could un-encrypt foreign transmissions on the fly. One time we weIn 2003 I was working for Cisco Systems and at the time we learned that the US Department of Defense had worked with Intel and other chip manufacturers to install in their hardware the ability to remotely disable any device using their technology with a certain radio frequency. Supposedly, this technology was used to help cripple the Iraqi air defense system when the US invaded.This was important to Cisco because we were working in security and cryptography and the NSA was forever trying to get us to corrupt our products so they could un-encrypt foreign transmissions on the fly. One time we were required to corrupt product that had been shipped to China and it started a major debate about our fiduciary responsibility to the country or to the customer. The issue was that if you sell a security product that you know is corrupted, you are knowingly committing fraud and are liable. As the Product Manager at the time I asked the NSA if they would stand behind us (and me as I might be personally liable) in court if we were discovered. Of course the answer from the NSA was “Hell no.”We were on our own. We then entered into a long debate about how to detect Easter eggs and other corruption introduced into security products unknowingly through another vendor’s corrupted hardware. The issue was never resolved but it should be known that our security source code HAD to be provided to the NSA in order to get FIPS certification and they made certain changes to it.So to answer your question, USA military technology is advanced far beyond anyone’s knowledge to describe the extent.On the other hand, the Chinese probably know more about our technology than we do since they perpetrated the greatest security breach in history by compromising the RSA key technology used by almost everyone in the world. We only learned of it through the vigilance of Lockheed-Martin who discovered the breach accidentally. But for months the Chinese had the key to almost every computer in the world.

They wade out into tHow does advanced technology help increase a country’s economy?Make it simple. Reduce the country in question to three people.Adam, Bob, and Cindy. All three live on a small island in the pacific. They have no predators on the island and no hope of rescue. Their three primary needs are food, shelter, and water.Each day all three wake and immediately set out to feed themselves. They wade out into the water to try and catch a fish by hand. They typically spend most of the day doing this before each has enough fish to survive. They each go to the river to drink and then they are too tired to do anything else. None of them have met a need for housing yet.One day Adam wakes up and is tired of the daily grind, so he takes the day off from fishing to fashion a spear. He’s not good at it and it takes him all day, meaning he has no fish at the end of the day. He goes to bed hungry, fish spear in hand. The next morning he wakes up, wades out with the others, and within a few short minutes begins to spear several fish. He notices he has more than he can eat that day, so he eats his fill and shares with the others. Everyone has more fish now because Adam created a fishing spear, technology they did not have before.The next morning, Adam has an idea. Answer: I was originally going to go with Carbon, however, seeing the plethora of answers featuring the versatile element which needs a whole branch of Chemistry to describe its illicit relationships, I decided to go with a lesser-known “black sheep”Technetium.He has a metallic descent, surrounded by stable elements on all sides. But he has one trait that makes him strange-In the nineteenth century, when the periodic table was created, his presence was predicted by the grand old man called Mendeleev who baptized him with the nameI was originally going to go with Carbon, however, seeing the plethora of answers featuring the versatile element which needs a whole branch of Chemistry to describe its illicit relationships, I decided to go with a lesser-known “black sheep”Technetium.He has a metallic descent, surrounded by stable elements on all sides. But he has one trait that makes him strange-In the nineteenth century, when the periodic table was created, his presence was predicted by the grand old man called Mendeleev who baptized him with the nameFrustrated with the wait of almost 70 years, in 1937, a group of Italian scientists decided to take the brave step.It was Technetium.Born out of these turbulent conditions, it was of no wonder that he was different from his cousins and the rest of the family. He was weird and unstable.He was radioactive.His longest-lived isotope has a half-life of just 4.2 million years, almost one-1000th of the age of the earth. This is what made him so difficult to be found in a natural environment. He tried to be like his siblings, forming similar compounds (halides, oxides, hydrides, complex ions, etc.), exhibiting variable oxidation states, and imitating the appearance of his glamorous cousin, Platinum.But no matter how he tried, he could never garner the attention of the stylish friend of his siblings, the mining industry, because he was almost never found in nature. In fact, most of the several tonnes of Technetium produced annually come from one source-Yes, when all his siblings have their magnificent origins in the Earth’s crust, he finds himself coming from waste matter. No wonder that he comes off as shy, awkward, and doesn’t usually show himself up with his well-known cousins and siblings.But, is that all about him?No, his origins never stopped him from becoming what he was destined to be.So, even in spite of all his weird characters, Technetium still manages to find a way to make himself useful to humanity.Technetium is a nice element. He certainly deserves more love! :)-Someone who has been fascinated with the periodic table since the age of 7.

chips, and nuclear power, and canned food, and drones, and aviation technology, and GPS, and infant formula, and indexing of websites for search engines, and bar codes, and touch screens, and vaccines, and windpower, and the accelerometer, and fire resistant clothing, and aerodynamic trucks, airbags, miniature cameras that fit in a webcam or cellphone, weather forecasting, and submarines, cellular technologWell, let’s think about it for a bit.What kind of technologies have been invented in the last century?We have things like radar, and microwave, and the internet, and satellites and computer chips, and nuclear power, and canned food, and drones, and aviation technology, and GPS, and infant formula, and indexing of websites for search engines, and bar codes, and touch screens, and vaccines, and windpower, and the accelerometer, and fire resistant clothing, and aerodynamic trucks, airbags, miniature cameras that fit in a webcam or cellphone, weather forecasting, and submarines, cellular technology and networks, RAM memory, hard disk drives, liquid-crystal displays, lithium batteries, so on.But all that kind of stuff was developed by having governments getting involved, funding research and science and so on.Which, as we all know, is a really inefficient method, it pretty much doesn’t work.Instead of this inefficient method that clearly doesn’t work, of having governments take part in research and development, we now have a much better strategy for innovation:Random guys in their garage!As we all know, that’s where all the true innovation comes from, random middle class dudes, who have ideas, and then do a startup in their garage.Either that, or huge corporations who invest in ways to extend their patents.So now, we have much more groundbreaking innovation.We have things like Amazon, who patented and made a fortune off one-click buying, the truly revolutionary idea of not making people click more than needed.Do you really think that government could have ever come up with a brilliant idea like that, huh?
